Me too: Anyone know why a server might not be booting from the ubuntu server disk on startup?
Is the BIOS configured to boot from CD automatically?
Is the CD-ROM configured to boot before the hard drive?
Also, is the system detecting the CD-ROM?
Once it's booted to the hard disk, check within Fedora to see if the CD-ROM drive is detected.
Sorry for being a linux n00b, but how do I go about doing that?

It's OK!  I forget the GUI method in Fedora (I believe there's a hardware manager, maybe someone using Fedora can confirm), but from the command-line you can type "sudo lshw | grep -A 15 cdrom", and look at the "logical name:" entries to see if your system has set the cdrom up.
You should see something like, "logical name:  /dev/dvd"
I see it, logical name: /dev/cdrom /dev/scd0 and /devsr0
Ok, this problem gets a little more complicated now.  Are you sure that the CD is bootable (has it worked before)?
It could be that the CD isn't bootable... that would explain the boot process skipping it.
Do you have K3b installed?
It has a very easy "Burn CD Image..." option, where once you've downloaded the .iso file from www.ubuntu.com, you can simply burn it using K3b.
I believe that should work ("sudo yum install k3b").
